repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem

The documentation flow (`gen_vimdoc.py`) has several issues:
- it's not very versatile
- depends on doxygen
- doesn't work well with Lua code as it requires an awkward filter script to convert it into pseudo-C.
- The intermediate XML files and filters makes it too much like a rube goldberg machine.

### Solution

Re-implement the flow using Lua, LPEG and treesitter.

- `gen_vimdoc.py` is now replaced with `gen_vimdoc.lua` and replicates a portion of the logic.
- `lua2dox.lua` is gone!
- No more XML files.
- Doxygen is now longer used and instead we now use:
  - LPEG for comment parsing (see `scripts/luacats_grammar.lua` and `scripts/cdoc_grammar.lua`).
  - LPEG for C parsing (see `scripts/cdoc_parser.lua`)
  - Lua patterns for Lua parsing (see `scripts/luacats_parser.lua`).
  - Treesitter for Markdown parsing (see `scripts/text_utils.lua`).
- The generated `runtime/doc/*.mpack` files have been removed.
   - `scripts/gen_eval_files.lua` now instead uses `scripts/cdoc_parser.lua` directly.
- Text wrapping is implemented in `scripts/text_utils.lua` and appears to produce more consistent results (the main contributer to the diff of this change).

### Todo

<details>
<summary>Details</summary>

- [x] Good word wrapping
- [x] Parse lists:
  - Do we need a markdown parser?
     - ~https://github.com/jgm/lunamark: Comprehensive but large~
     - ~https://github.com/sebcat/lpeg-markdown: Too simple, doesn't handle nested lists.~
     - UPDATE: using the tree-sitter parser we bundle
- [x] Also make it work for C files.
- [x] Support custom LuaCATs extensions
  - [x] `@note`
  - [x] `@deprecated`
  - [x] `@defgroup` - REMOVED
  - [x] `@brief` 
  - [x] `@since`
- [x] Remove `gen_vimdoc.py`
- [x] Remove `lua2dox.lua`
- [x] Generate docs for Luadoc classes
   - Done but commented out in this PR.

</details>

### Future Work

- Lua objects documented with `@class` will now be easy to generate documentation for. The code for that is already included (but commented out) in this change.
  - This will additionally allow us to document the full types of function arguments by using `@field` instead of hand formatted text.
- Editorial changes to increase consistency with things like: help tags and function names. E.g. whether to include the `vim.` prefix or not.
- Switch the Lua parsing from Lua patterns to either a LPEG or Treesitter based parser.
- Support for more custom `@` annotations.
- Graduate the markdown renderer in `text_utils.lua` and use in LSP hover.

---

### Notes:
- The logic for generation function name/tags is still a bit of a mess. However now we have a bit more semantic information on the Lua files, this should now be easier to cleanup and create a more standard convention for documenting the various categories of functions.

- Before:
  ```
  $ wc -l scripts/gen_vimdoc.py scripts/lua2dox.lua
   1766 scripts/gen_vimdoc.py
    532 scripts/lua2dox.lua
   2298 total
  ```
  This PR:
  ```
  $ wc -l scripts/gen_vimdoc.lua scripts/luacats_parser.lua scripts/cdoc_grammar.lua scripts/cdoc_parser.lua scripts/text_utils.lua
    792 scripts/gen_vimdoc.lua
    521 scripts/luacats_parser.lua
     87 scripts/cdoc_grammar.lua
    223 scripts/cdoc_parser.lua
    242 scripts/text_utils.lua
   1865 total
  ```

comment_data.body: Probably filter out classes beginning with `_`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -361,6 +361,144 @@ Example: >lua
 ==============================================================================
 Lua module: vim.diagnostic                                    *diagnostic-api*
 
+*vim.diagnostic.Handler*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {show?} (`fun(namespace: integer, bufnr: integer, diagnostics: vim.Diagnostic[], opts?: vim.diagnostic.OptsResolved)`)
+        â€¢ {hide?} (`fun(namespace:integer, bufnr:integer)`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {severity?} (`vim.diagnostic.SeverityFilter`)
+        â€¢ {source?} (`boolean|string`)
+        â€¢ {prefix?} (`string|function`)
+        â€¢ {suffix?} (`string|function`)
+        â€¢ {spacing?} (`integer`)
+        â€¢ {format?} (`function`)
+        â€¢ {hl_mode?} (`'replace'|'combine'|'blend'`)
+        â€¢ {virt_text?} (`{[1]:string,[2]:any}[]`)
+        â€¢ {virt_text_pos?} (`'eol'|'overlay'|'right_align'|'inline'`)
+        â€¢ {virt_text_win_col?} (`integer`)
+        â€¢ {virt_text_hide?} (`boolean`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic.Opts.Float*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {bufnr?} (`integer`)
+        â€¢ {namespace?} (`integer`)
+        â€¢ {scope?} (`'line'|'buffer'|'cursor'|'c'|'l'|'b'`)
+        â€¢ {pos?} (`integer|{[1]:integer,[2]:integer}`)
+        â€¢ {severity_sort?} (`boolean|{reverse?:boolean}`)
+        â€¢ {severity?} (`vim.diagnostic.SeverityFilter`)
+        â€¢ {header?} (`string|{[1]:string,[2]:any}`)
+        â€¢ {source?} (`boolean|string`)
+        â€¢ {format?} (`fun(diagnostic:vim.Diagnostic): string`)
+        â€¢ {prefix?} (`string|table`)
+        â€¢ {suffix?} (`string|table`)
+        â€¢ {focus_id?} (`string`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic.Opts*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {float?} (`boolean|vim.diagnostic.Opts.Float`)
+        â€¢ {update_in_insert?} (`boolean`)
+        â€¢ {underline?} (`boolean|vim.diagnostic.Opts.Underline`)
+        â€¢ {virtual_text?} (`boolean|vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText`)
+        â€¢ {signs?} (`boolean|vim.diagnostic.Opts.Signs`)
+        â€¢ {severity_sort?} (`boolean|{reverse?:boolean}`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic.OptsResolved*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {float} (`vim.diagnostic.Opts.Float`)
+        â€¢ {update_in_insert} (`boolean`)
+        â€¢ {underline} (`vim.diagnostic.Opts.Underline`)
+        â€¢ {virtual_text} (`vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText`)
+        â€¢ {signs} (`vim.diagnostic.Opts.Signs`)
+        â€¢ {severity_sort} (`{reverse?:boolean}`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic.Opts.Signs*
+
+    Fields: ~
+        â€¢ {severity?} (`vim.diagnostic.SeverityFilter`)
+        â€¢ {priority?} (`integer`)
+        â€¢ {text?} (`table<vim.diagnostic.Severity,string>`)
+        â€¢ {numhl?} (`table<vim.diagnostic.Severity,string>`)
+        â€¢ {linehl?} (`table<vim.diagnostic.Severity,string>`)
+        â€¢ {texthl?} (`table<vim.diagnostic.Severity,string>`)
+
+*vim.diagnostic._extmark*

comment_data.body: Would it make sense to use this instead of our own LPEG grammar: https://github.com/tree-sitter-grammars/tree-sitter-luadoc
can we name it `gen_vimdoc.lua` (or `gen_help.lua`), for consistency
Sure as this develops, I'll rename this appropriately. Right now this is still driven through gen_vimdoc.py and is only used for Lua files.
Not if we want to support `@note` and friends.
ðŸ‘€
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -880,8 +878,8 @@ start({bufnr}, {lang})                                *vim.treesitter.start()*
     Can be used in an ftplugin or FileType autocommand.
 
     Note: By default, disables regex syntax highlighting, which may be
-    required for some plugins. In this case, add `vim.bo.syntax = 'on'` after
-    the call to `start`.
+    required for some plugins. In this case, add ``vim.bo.syntax = 'on'``

comment_data.body: This is what it is in `treesitter.lua`. My new scripts have taken it verbatim.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- "references". |lua-guide-variables| For example, using `vim.fn.remove()` on
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,99 +1,96 @@
----@defgroup lua-vimscript
+--- @brief Nvim Lua provides an interface or "bridge" to Vimscript variables and
+--- functions, and editor commands and options.
 ---
----@brief Nvim Lua provides an interface or "bridge" to Vimscript variables and
----functions, and editor commands and options.
----
----Objects passed over this bridge are COPIED (marshalled): there are no
----"references". |lua-guide-variables| For example, using \`vim.fn.remove()\` on
----a Lua list copies the list object to Vimscript and does NOT modify the Lua
----list:
+--- Objects passed over this bridge are COPIED (marshalled): there are no
+--- "references". |lua-guide-variables| For example, using \`vim.fn.remove()\` on

```
vim.lpeg                                                            *vim.lpeg*
    *LPeg* is a new pattern-matching library for Lua, based on [Parsing
    Expression Grammars](https://bford.info/packrat/) (PEGs).
```

is this still ok the remove?

comment_data.body: Q: does our LuaCATS parser support `@return <type> <name> <desc>`? While gendoc is fine, LuaLS treated `Parsed` as the name of the return value. This was a placeholder for `<name>` to make both LuaLS (anonymous return values) and gendoc happy.

comment_data.body: Why 78?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,242 @@
+local fmt = string.format
+
+local INDENTATION = 4
+
+local M = {}
+
+local function contains(t, xs)
+  return vim.tbl_contains(xs, t)
+end
+
+--- @param text string
+--- @return MDNode
+local function parse_md(text)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.languagetree.new(text, 'markdown', {
+    injections = { markdown = '' },
+  })
+
+  local root = parser:parse(true)[1]:root()
+
+  local EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE = {
+    list = true,
+    list_item = true,
+    section = true,
+    document = true,
+    fenced_code_block = true,
+    fenced_code_block_delimiter = true,
+  }
+
+  --- @param node TSNode
+  --- @return MDNode?
+  local function extract(node)
+    local ntype = node:type()
+
+    if ntype:match('^%p$') or contains(ntype, { 'block_continuation' }) then
+      return
+    end
+
+    --- @type table<any,any>
+    local ret = { type = ntype }
+
+    if not EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE[ntype] then
+      ret.text = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, text)
+    end
+
+    for child, child_field in node:iter_children() do
+      local e = extract(child)
+      if child_field then
+        ret[child_field] = e
+      else
+        table.insert(ret, e)
+      end
+    end
+
+    return ret
+  end
+
+  return extract(root) or {}
+end
+
+--- @param x string
+--- @param start_indent integer
+--- @param indent integer
+--- @param text_width integer
+--- @return string
+function M.wrap(x, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+  text_width = text_width or 78

comment_data.body:

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,242 @@
+local fmt = string.format
+
+local INDENTATION = 4
+
+local M = {}
+
+local function contains(t, xs)
+  return vim.tbl_contains(xs, t)
+end
+
+--- @param text string
+--- @return MDNode
+local function parse_md(text)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.languagetree.new(text, 'markdown', {
+    injections = { markdown = '' },
+  })
+
+  local root = parser:parse(true)[1]:root()
+
+  local EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE = {
+    list = true,
+    list_item = true,
+    section = true,
+    document = true,
+    fenced_code_block = true,
+    fenced_code_block_delimiter = true,
+  }
+
+  --- @param node TSNode
+  --- @return MDNode?
+  local function extract(node)
+    local ntype = node:type()
+
+    if ntype:match('^%p$') or contains(ntype, { 'block_continuation' }) then
+      return
+    end
+
+    --- @type table<any,any>
+    local ret = { type = ntype }
+
+    if not EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE[ntype] then
+      ret.text = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, text)
+    end
+
+    for child, child_field in node:iter_children() do
+      local e = extract(child)
+      if child_field then
+        ret[child_field] = e
+      else
+        table.insert(ret, e)
+      end
+    end
+
+    return ret
+  end
+
+  return extract(root) or {}
+end
+
+--- @param x string
+--- @param start_indent integer
+--- @param indent integer
+--- @param text_width integer
+--- @return string
+function M.wrap(x, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+  text_width = text_width or 78
+  local words = vim.split(vim.trim(x), '%s+')
+  local parts = { string.rep(' ', start_indent) } --- @type string[]
+  local count = indent
+
+  for i, w in ipairs(words) do
+    if count > indent and count + #w > text_width - 1 then
+      parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+      parts[#parts + 1] = string.rep(' ', indent)
+      count = indent
+    elseif i ~= 1 then
+      parts[#parts + 1] = ' '
+      count = count + 1
+    end
+    count = count + #w
+    parts[#parts + 1] = w
+  end
+
+  return (table.concat(parts):gsub('%s+\n', '\n'):gsub('\n+$', ''))
+end
+
+--- @param node MDNode
+--- @param start_indent integer
+--- @param indent integer
+--- @param text_width integer
+--- @param level integer
+--- @return string[]
+local function render_md(node, start_indent, indent, text_width, level, is_list)
+  local parts = {} --- @type string[]
+
+  -- For debugging
+  local add_tag = false
+  -- local add_tag = true
+
+  if add_tag then
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '<' .. node.type .. '>'
+  end
+
+  if node.type == 'paragraph' then
+    local text = assert(node.text)
+    text = text:gsub('(%s)%*(%w+)%*(%s)', '%1%2%3')
+    text = text:gsub('(%s)_(%w+)_(%s)', '%1%2%3')
+    text = text:gsub('\\|', '|')
+    text = text:gsub('\\%*', '*')
+    text = text:gsub('\\_', '_')
+    parts[#parts + 1] = M.wrap(text, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+  elseif node.type == 'code_fence_content' then
+    local lines = vim.split(node.text:gsub('\n%s*$', ''), '\n')
+
+    local cindent = indent + INDENTATION
+    if level > 3 then
+      -- The tree-sitter markdown parser doesn't parse the code blocks indents
+      -- correctly in lists. Fudge it!
+      lines[1] = '    ' .. lines[1] -- Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

@@ -0,0 +1,242 @@
+local fmt = string.format
+
+local INDENTATION = 4
+
+local M = {}
+
+local function contains(t, xs)
+  return vim.tbl_contains(xs, t)
+end
+
+--- @param text string
+--- @return MDNode
+local function parse_md(text)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.languagetree.new(text, 'markdown', {
+    injections = { markdown = '' },
+  })
+
+  local root = parser:parse(true)[1]:root()
+
+  local EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE = {
+    list = true,
+    list_item = true,
+    section = true,
+    document = true,
+    fenced_code_block = true,
+    fenced_code_block_delimiter = true,
+  }
+
+  --- @param node TSNode
+  --- @return MDNode?
+  local function extract(node)
+    local ntype = node:type()
+
+    if ntype:match('^%p$') or contains(ntype, { 'block_continuation' }) then
+      return
+    end
+
+    --- @type table<any,any>
+    local ret = { type = ntype }
+
+    if not EXCLUDE_TEXT_TYPE[ntype] then
+      ret.text = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, text)
+    end
+
+    for child, child_field in node:iter_children() do
+      local e = extract(child)
+      if child_field then
+        ret[child_field] = e
+      else
+        table.insert(ret, e)
+      end
+    end
+
+    return ret
+  end
+
+  return extract(root) or {}
+end
+
+--- @param x string
+--- @param start_indent integer
+--- @param indent integer
+--- @param text_width integer
+--- @return string
+function M.wrap(x, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+  text_width = text_width or 78
+  local words = vim.split(vim.trim(x), '%s+')
+  local parts = { string.rep(' ', start_indent) } --- @type string[]
+  local count = indent
+
+  for i, w in ipairs(words) do
+    if count > indent and count + #w > text_width - 1 then
+      parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+      parts[#parts + 1] = string.rep(' ', indent)
+      count = indent
+    elseif i ~= 1 then
+      parts[#parts + 1] = ' '
+      count = count + 1
+    end
+    count = count + #w
+    parts[#parts + 1] = w
+  end
+
+  return (table.concat(parts):gsub('%s+\n', '\n'):gsub('\n+$', ''))
+end
+
+--- @param node MDNode
+--- @param start_indent integer
+--- @param indent integer
+--- @param text_width integer
+--- @param level integer
+--- @return string[]
+local function render_md(node, start_indent, indent, text_width, level, is_list)
+  local parts = {} --- @type string[]
+
+  -- For debugging
+  local add_tag = false
+  -- local add_tag = true
+
+  if add_tag then
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '<' .. node.type .. '>'
+  end
+
+  if node.type == 'paragraph' then
+    local text = assert(node.text)
+    text = text:gsub('(%s)%*(%w+)%*(%s)', '%1%2%3')
+    text = text:gsub('(%s)_(%w+)_(%s)', '%1%2%3')
+    text = text:gsub('\\|', '|')
+    text = text:gsub('\\%*', '*')
+    text = text:gsub('\\_', '_')
+    parts[#parts + 1] = M.wrap(text, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+  elseif node.type == 'code_fence_content' then
+    local lines = vim.split(node.text:gsub('\n%s*$', ''), '\n')
+
+    local cindent = indent + INDENTATION
+    if level > 3 then
+      -- The tree-sitter markdown parser doesn't parse the code blocks indents
+      -- correctly in lists. Fudge it!
+      lines[1] = '    ' .. lines[1] -- Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯
+      cindent = indent - level
+      local _, initial_indent = lines[1]:find('^%s*')
+      initial_indent = initial_indent + cindent
+      if initial_indent < indent then
+        cindent = indent - INDENTATION
+      end
+    end
+
+    for _, l in ipairs(lines) do
+      if #l > 0 then
+        parts[#parts + 1] = string.rep(' ', cindent)
+        parts[#parts + 1] = l
+      end
+      parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+    end
+  elseif node.type == 'fenced_code_block' then
+    parts[#parts + 1] = string.rep(' ', indent)
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '>'
+    for _, child in ipairs(node) do
+      -- if child.type == 'info_string' then

comment_data.body:
I'm not even sure `INDENTATION` is even correct here, though it happens to be the same. This is a complete fudge that just minimizes the diff and seems to produce the most consistent results.

The real action here is to fix the range generation in the Markdown parser directly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+    text = text:gsub('\\_', '_')
+    parts[#parts + 1] = M.wrap(text, start_indent, indent, text_width)
+    parts[#parts + 1] = '\n'
+  elseif node.type == 'code_fence_content' then
+    local lines = vim.split(node.text:gsub('\n%s*$', ''), '\n')
+
+    local cindent = indent + INDENTATION
+    if level > 3 then
+      -- The tree-sitter markdown parser doesn't parse the code blocks indents
+      -- correctly in lists. Fudge it!
+      lines[1] = '    ' .. lines[1] -- Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

comment_data.body:
Yes, getting all the tags to match was a pain.

Instead I've gone with a slightly more generic scheme:

```lua
--- @param fun nvim.luacats.parser.fun
--- @return string
local function fn_helptag_fmt_common(fun)
  local fn_sfx = fun.table and '' or '()'
  if fun.classvar then
    return fmt('*%s:%s%s*', fun.classvar, fun.name, fn_sfx)
  end
  if fun.module then
    return fmt('*%s.%s%s*', fun.module, fun.name, fn_sfx)
  end
  return fmt('*%s%s*', fun.name, fn_sfx)
end
```

Here we are documenting class/object methods as `*Class:method()*` which is generally consistent with what we do with other files.

 In addition, its regex-like interface is available as |vim.re|
 (https://www.inf.puc-rio.br/~roberto/lpeg/re.html).
 
+
+
+
+Pattern:match({subject}, {init})                             *Pattern:match()*


comment_data.body: Fixed now.

comment_regular_data.body:
No worries but this is incredibly rough.

It's not obvious, but the code here basically allows us to generate full docs for functions too, so I might pivot this to try and remove the doxygen middleman and do classes later.

>  Do we need a markdown parser?

We have a tree-sitter markdown parser. Is LPEG preferred for some reason?

If this is done using treesitter, then we could later replace `gen_vimdoc.py` entirely, because we could feed the result of treesitter C parser into the tooling from this PR.

I'm really not sure treesitter is the right tool for this. Yes treesitter provides parsers, but it doesn't provide great APIs for what we're trying to achieve. The node structure, especially for C and Markdown, do not have a  an easy to follow hierarchy so there would need to be some normalisation step to put everything into a good shape.

Also note the Markdown parser doesn't have an active maintainer and is currently implemented as two separate parsers, so I'd be pretty nervous about depending on that.

I'm sure if enough time is put into it that we could make it work, but I feel it is reuse for the sake of reuse whilst making the stack a lot taller.

For C and Lua I don't think we really need a parser. Regexp should be good enough for parsing out prototypes. Otherwise a simple lpeg pattern can help us cover anything less trivial. It doesn't need to cover the whole language; just anything that follows a doc block. We also already depend on an lpeg grammar for the C API generators.

> If this is done using treesitter, then we could later replace gen_vimdoc.py entirely, because we could feed the result of treesitter C parser into the tooling from this PR.

I think we can replace gen_vimdoc.py by using most of the code here for C. We just need different patterns for the function prototypes.

> treesitter ... doesn't provide great APIs for what we're trying to achieve. The node structure, especially for C and Markdown, do not have a an easy to follow hierarchy ... Also note the Markdown parser doesn't have an active maintainer ...
>
> For C and Lua I don't think we really need a parser. Regexp should be good enough for parsing out prototypes. Otherwise a simple lpeg pattern can help us cover anything less trivial.

Interesting. Let's mention that in ~~luacats_parser.lua~~ `gen_vimdoc.lua` and the commit message, for future reference.

Ok, so I've spent quite a bit more time on this and gone through a few rabbit holes.

Creating a simple markdown parser using LPEG isn't reasonably possible AFAIK since you need to somehow keep track of indentation for identifying blocks.

Next I tried looking at some other Markdown parsers implemented manually.
- First looked at https://github.com/mpeterv/markdown and it's _ok_, but wasn't particularly happy with its design.
- Then found https://github.com/frostming/marko, which is implemented in Python (very good Python I might add). So I tried to see if I could remove everything we didn't need and port to Lua. Turns out with just the block level stuff (list, paragraphs and code blocks) you're still left with 500-800 LOC. And that's with a good design.

**TLDR**

So I finally gave in and attempted to use the tree-sitter parser we bundle. I've got it to work pretty well, but it certainly has some challenges. One example being codeblocks seems to be parsed with incorrect ranges when in nested blocks like lists. It also doesn't correctly parse some stuff because of indentation in places.

I've been able to generate `diagnostic.txt` 95% the same to how it was with `gen_vimdoc.py` which I'm pretty happy with so this seems like a good route.

> One example being codeblocks seems to be parsed with incorrect ranges when in nested blocks like lists.

We own the markdown parser now, so it should be possible to get fixes in relatively easily, if this helps.

All the Lua files are now done. Feel free to review.

Now to tackle C...

Finished C. 

Negative diffstat achieved!

Now need to fix everything I broke. i.e. anything that depended on the mpack files outputted from `gen_vimdoc.py`.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: feat(docs): replace gen_vimdoc.py with gen_vimdoc.lua
